byline.contributor: Liz Alderman reported from Athens, and James Kanter from Brussels. Reporting was contributed by Alissa J. Rubin from Paris, Alison Smale from Berlin, Jack Ewing from Frankfurt, and Niki Kitsantonis from Athens.
byline.original: By LIZ ALDERMAN and JAMES KANTER

abstract: Greek Prime Min Alexis Tsipras presents plan of austerity measures, including pension cuts, to gain new bailout package from European creditors; asks for three-year loan of 53.5 billion euros, or $59 billion and commitment to help Greece restructure its massive debt; it is unclear whether latest strategy reflects political determination to negotiate deal that keeps Greece in eurozone.
lead_paragraph: After grim predictions of collapse in Greece, a scramble was underway to work out the details of a new plan to bring the country back from the brink.

headline.main: Greek Plan Accepts Austerity to Get Debt Relief
headline.print_headline: Greek Plan Accepts Austerity to Get Debt Relief

snippet: After grim predictions of collapse in Greece, a scramble was underway to work out the details of a new plan to bring the country back from the brink.
